Award.AwardTitle: Physics of virus assembly: energetics and dynamics
Award.AbstractNarration:
TECHNICAL SUMMARY

This award supports theoretical research and education at the interface of materials science, soft matter physics and biology. The objective of the proposed research is to elucidate the role of RNA in the formation of virus particles. The PI proposes to explore the impact of RNA on the assembly of virus particles focusing on its branching structure and configurations inside capsids.
The goal of the research is to investigate the role of RNA in the formation of spherical capsids with icosahedral symmetry and HIV capsids with conical structures. This will be achieved by using a combination of field theoretical methods developed for branched polymers and the Poisson-Boltzmann approximation for electrostatic interactions. The analytical theory will be augmented by Monte Carlo and Brownian dynamics simulations. This methodology will be modified to study kinetics of formation of immature HIV particles, membrane deformation dynamics and capsid protein transport.

Understanding the formation of viral shells could influence progress in emerging areas of nanoscience, nanotechnology, and gene therapy. In particular, this research could contribute to alternative antiviral strategies based on direct interference with the assembly of infectious viral particles.

This award will contribute to the education and training of undergraduate, graduate and postgraduate students in a multidisciplinary environment providing them with expertise in soft condensed matter and biological physics. The PI will organize an outreach program for the middle school minority students in Riverside that is aimed to increase participation of underrepresented groups in science and technology.


NONTECHNICAL SUMMARY

This award supports theoretical research and education at the interface of materials science, soft matter physics and biology. In its simplest form, a virus is composed of a protein shell called the capsid that encloses the viral genome. Under the appropriate conditions, the capsid proteins assemble spontaneously around its genome. It is now widely accepted that RNA has an important role in the stability of viral particles. The PI will investigate the role of RNA in the assembly of spherical, cylindrical and conical viral shells. In particular, she aims to explain the spontaneous formation of conical structures, a distinguished feature of HIV capsids. The main question that will be addressed: Does the interaction with genome contribute to the stability of HIV conical structure?

Understanding the formation of viral shells could influence progress in emerging areas of nanoscience, nanotechnology, and gene therapy. In particular, this research could result in alternative antiviral strategies based on direct interference with the assembly of infectious viral particles.

This award will contribute to the education and training of undergraduate, graduate and postgraduate students in a multidisciplinary environment providing them with expertise in soft condensed matter and biological physics. The PI will organize an outreach program for the middle school minority students in Riverside that is aimed to increase participation of underrepresented groups in science and technology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The spontaneous assembly of viruses from the constituent proteins and genome is widely recognized as a paradigm for self-assembly of complex molecular structures in biology, yet the underlying physical principles are not well understood. During the term of this NSF award, we have made progress in deciphering the role of electrostatics, entropy and elastic interactions in the assembly of viral particles. We provided the biology, material science and physics communities with novel quantitative knowledge of the physical interactions governing the formation of viruses. We have studied the self-assembly of Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) and many spherical viruses both in the absence and presence of genome as highlighted below.

  1. RNA topology: In most theoretical studies published to date, RNA is modeled as a linear polyelectrolyte chain. However, base pairing between nucleotides leads to a highly branched structure of RNA. Considering the combined effect of RNA base-pairing and the genome-protein electrostatic interactions, we explained why in the majority of RNA viruses, the number of negative charges on the encapsidated RNA is larger than the number of positive charges on capsid proteins, an intriguing phenomena. Moreover, we found that RNA topology could result in negative osmotic pressures while a linear polymer causes positive osmotic pressures under the same conditions, explaining the reason behind the spontaneous assembly of RNA viruses. We also showed that the larger the inherent propensity to form branched points, the larger is the optimal encapsulated RNA length, consistent with in vitro experiments. This could explain the “puzzling” selective preference for viral RNAs compared to the cellular RNAs, as it is shown that the latter has a more branched structure.
  2. HIV assembly: The proteins of HIV shell spontaneously assemble around the genome into a protein shell, which can take on a variety of shapes classified as conical, cylindrical, and irregular. The majority of capsids observed in vivo are conical in shape while in vitro experiments have shown a preference for cylindrical shells. Our calculations revealed the role of RNA on the structure of capsids. We showed that the formation of conical shell is energetically preferable when the genome does not interact with the capsid, which seems to be the case in in vivo experiments. Conversely, if RNA is attracted to the capsid proteins as in the in vitro experiment, cylindrical shells are energetically preferred. We also studied the the Kinetic pathways of assembly of HIV shells. The spherical non-infectious immature HIV particle forms during budding (or exiting) of the virus from the cell. The process of maturation of the immature HIV that leads to the formation of infectious mature HIV with its characteristic conical core is under intense debate. The kinetic pathways and dynamics of formation of HIV remain poorly understood. Two distinct models were proposed for HIV maturation. In the “de novo” model, the immature virus completely disassembles, generating a pool of protein subunits from which a mature core reassembles de novo. By contrast, the displacive model assumes that the mature shell formation involves a direct, non-diffusional remodeling of the immature proteins to the mature ones without disassembly. We developed a model and proposed a new alternative pathway for the formation of conical shells, which included a sequential combination of displacive rearrangement and growth. These findings explained the intriguing pathway of assembly of HIV conical shells.
  3. Formation of symmetric spherical shells: While the equilibrium studies have been able to explain the structure of spherical viral shells, the kinetic pathways and dynamics of formation of icosahedral shells remain poorly understood. In addition to viral shells, highly symmetric nano-shells are found in many other biological systems such as clathrin shells, responsible for membrane trafficking in cells. A question that naturally arises here is, what are the rules that govern the self-assembly of finite numbers of protein subunits into precise structures? Why do we observe symmetric structures and in particular icosahedral symmetry in disparate systems? We have been looking for the minimum requirements for the formation of closed nano-shells with icosahedral symmetry. Despite the sensitivity of the symmetry of shells to the exact location of pentagons, under many experimental conditions the self-assembly of perfect icosahedral virus capsids or clathrin shells is robust and efficient. We found that the mismatch between the desired spontaneous radius of curvature and the local radius of curvature induced by a pentamer or hexamer tends to suppress the formation of similar types of capsomers in the vicinity of each other. This suppression tends to lead to the small shells being highly symmetric in nature. This effect seems to be short ranged, which can explain why larger clathrin vesicles display no symmetry and larger viruses need scaffolding proteins to form shells with icosahedral symmetry.

Broader Impacts: Understanding the assembly of viral particles will advance our knowledge in the emerging areas of nanoscience, nanotechnology, gene therapy, and the design of nano-shells.
